questions.text:
A 10-year-old young male child came to pediatric OPD with complaints of sudden onset fever and hematuria. The patient had given a history of taking treatment for a common cold and sore throat before one week from the family physician.
Following are the results of the investigations:
Hemoglobin:12.5g/dl
Total WBC Count:12,500/cmm
Differential count: Neutrophilia
Urine routine and microscopic examination: brown colour urine with presence of red cells. Which of the following renal disease is the most likely diagnosis based on above history and investigations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical vignette of hematuria following an upper respiratory tract infection is acute proliferative glomerulonephritis.

  • Acute proliferative glomerulonephritis represents a group of conditions defined by a histological pattern involving widespread glomerular cell proliferation and an influx of leukocytes, often caused by immune complex deposition.
  • It presents as nephritic syndrome which is marked by hematuria, hypertension, proteinuria, and azotemia.
  • The triggering antigen may originate either from an external infection or from within the body. A prime example is post-infectious glomerulonephritis, especially poststreptococcal GN, which generally occurs 1 - 4 weeks after a streptococcal throat or skin infection (like impetigo).
  • Poststreptococcal GN results from immune complexes containing streptococcal antigens and antibodies. Only certain nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci (notably types 12, 4, and 1, identifiable by M protein typing) are responsible for most cases.
  • The interval between infection and nephritis aligns with the time needed for antibody production and immune complex formation. These immune complexes, especially those containing the exotoxin SpeB (streptococcal pyogenic exotoxin B), activate complement and cause inflammation.
  • Similar glomerulonephritis can also occur from other bacterial, viral, or parasitic infections (e.g., endocarditis, hepatitis B/C, varicella, malaria).
  • Histologically, the glomeruli are enlarged and hypercellular due to leukocyte infiltration (neutrophils and monocytes), proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells, and sometimes crescent formation.
  • Immunofluorescence reveals granular IgG and C3 deposits, and sometimes IgM, in the mesangium and along the GBM, indicating immune complex-mediated injury.
  • Electron microscopy shows irregular, dense subepithelial deposits ("humps"), with additional subendothelial and mesangial involvement, especially early in the disease.
  • A typical presentation in children includes sudden onset of malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and dark (cola-colored) urine 1-2 weeks after a sore throat.
  • Edema, mild proteinuria (<1 g/day), hematuria, and moderate hypertension are common.
  • Over 95% of affected children recover renal function with supportive therapy. A small subset may progress to rapidly progressive GN.

Explanation of other options:

Membranous nephropathy (Option B): Membranous nephropathy presents with insidious onset of nephrotic syndrome characterised by marked proteinuria, generalised edema, and hyperlipidemia. Most cases are idiopathic, but secondary forms are linked to drugs, infections, malignancies, autoimmune diseases, and systemic conditions. Histologically, electron-dense deposits cause spike-like projections from the basement membrane.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option C): One of the most frequent cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults, marked by focal and segmental scarring of glomeruli, often linked to podocyte injury and presenting with proteinuria, hypertension, hematuria, and azotemia.It is considered a podocytopathy, much like minimal change disease.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option D): It is not a single disease but a form of immune-mediated glomerular injury and is currently classified into two types: Type I, involving immune complexes of IgG and complement, and Type II (dense deposit disease), which is driven by complement dysregulation. Clinically, MPGN often appears during adolescence or early adulthood with nephrotic syndrome and may also include a nephritic component such as hematuria or mild proteinuria.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is recovering from skin infection with crusts formation. He is treated with antibiotics. One week later, he develops malaise with nausea and a slight fever and passes dark brown urine. A kidney biopsy performed at this stage is shown below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario of hematuria, malaise, and fever following skin infection(likely impetigo) and histopathological image showing hypercellular glomerulus is suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

  • Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (GN) is an immune complex-mediated kidney condition that typically arises 1 to 4 weeks following a streptococcal throat or skin infection, characterized by glomerular inflammation due to immune responses against nephritogenic bacterial antigens.
  • Only specific strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci, primarily types 12, 4, and 1 are involved
  • Histologically, glomeruli appear swollen and filled with inflammatory cells, including neutrophils and monocytes, along with proliferation of mesangial and endothelial cells, and occasionally crescent formation.
  • Immunofluorescence reveals granular deposits of IgG and C3, and at times IgM within the mesangium and along the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
  • Electron microscopy shows distinctive subepithelial deposits or "humps", often accompanied by early subendothelial and mesangial involvement.
  • Clinically, affected children typically develop symptoms like fatigue, fever, nausea, reduced urine output, and dark-colored urine. Other signs include periorbital edema, microscopic hematuria, mild proteinuria, and moderately elevated blood pressure.
  • Prognosis in children is favorable, with over 95% recovering with supportive treatment; however, a minority may progress to a rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Explanation of other options:

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (Option B): Rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical presentation marked by abrupt and progressive decline in renal function due to severe glomerular injury, commonly showing crescents in glomeruli, but it is not a diagnosis with a single cause.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (Option C): MPGN is not considered a distinct disease entity but rather a morphological manifestation of underlying immune-mediated damage to the glomeruli. It presents as nephrotic syndrome and is currently categorized into two primary forms: Type I, which involves deposits of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and complement, and Type II (also referred to as dense deposit disease) where dysregulation of the complement pathway is the main pathogenic factor.

Membranous nephropathy (Option D): Membranous nephropathy begins gradually with nephrotic syndrome marked by significant protein loss in urine, widespread swelling, and elevated lipid levels. While the majority of cases occur without an obvious underlying cause (idiopathic), some are secondary to factors such as certain medications, infections, cancers, autoimmune disorders, or systemic diseases. On microscopic examination, a hallmark feature is the presence of electron-dense immune deposits along the subepithelial aspect of the glomerular basement membrane, which stimulate the formation of distinctive spike-like extensions.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is recovering from skin infection with crusts formation. A culture from lesions shows Streptococcus pyogenes and is treated with antibiotics. One week later, she develops malaise with nausea and a slight fever and passes dark brown urine. Kidney biopsy performed at this stage is shown below. Based on your diagnosis, electron microscopy will show amorphous deposition at?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amorphous deposition in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis can be seen in all of the mentioned sites.

  • Poststreptococcal GN commonly develops 1 - 4 weeks after infections of the throat or skin caused by specific nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci, especially types 12, 4, and 1.
  • The disease is driven by immune complex formation against bacterial antigens, which leads to inflammation of the glomeruli.
  • Microscopy shows enlarged glomeruli filled with neutrophils and monocytes, mesangial and endothelial cell proliferation, and sometimes crescent formation.
  • Immunofluorescence typically detects granular IgG and C3 deposits, with occasional IgM, located in the mesangium and along the GBM.
  • On electron microscopy, the hallmark feature is subepithelial "hump-like" electron-dense deposits. Subendothelial, mesangial, and intramembranous deposits can also be seen.
  • Clinically, children often present with symptoms like fatigue, fever, nausea, oliguria, and hematuria, along with periorbital swelling, hematuria, mild proteinuria, and moderately raised blood pressure.
  • The prognosis is generally excellent in pediatric cases, with most recovering fully on supportive care, although a small fraction may advance to rapidly progressive forms.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is recovering from skin infection with crusts formation. Two weeks later, she developed hematuria, fever, and malaise. A diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is made. Kidney biopsy performed at this stage is shown below. Immunofluorescence study will show characteristics granular deposits of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Immunofluorescence done in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is marked by granular deposits of IgG and C3.

  • Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis is an immune complex-mediated glomerular disease that typically arises a few weeks after streptococcal infection especially in children.
  • It usually manifests 1 to 4 weeks following a throat or skin infection caused by certain nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci, most notably types 12, 4, and 1.
  • It results from the deposition of immune complexes targeting streptococcal antigens, which incites glomerular inflammation.
  • Light microscopy reveals enlarged glomeruli packed with neutrophils and monocytes, as well as hyperplasia of mesangial and endothelial cells, and sometimes crescent formation.
  • Granular deposits of IgG and C3, occasionally accompanied by IgM, are observed in the mesangium and along the glomerular basement membrane under immunofluorescence.
  • Electron microscopy highlights subepithelial deposits resembling "humps", and additional involvement of subendothelial, mesangial, or intramembranous areas may occur.
  • Clinically, affected children present with symptoms like malaise, fever, nausea, decreased urine output, dark urine, periorbital edema, microscopic hematuria, mild proteinuria, and mild to moderate hypertension.
  • Most pediatric patients respond well to conservative management, although a minority may develop a rapidly progressive form.

questions.text: The images given below are the light microscopy & immunofluorescence findings of renal biopsy. The immunofluorescence shows deposits of immunoglobulin G and C3 in a diffuse granular pattern along the glomerular capillary wall and mesangium. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario, light microscopy findings of enlarged hypercellular glomerulus, and granular deposits on immunofluorescence suggests a diagnosis of post-infectious glomerulonephritis.

  • Post-infectious glomerulonephritis particularly post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis commonly develops within 1 to 4 weeks following pharyngitis or a skin infection caused by specific nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci.
  • The disease process is driven by immune complexes directed against streptococcal antigens, leading to inflammatory changes in the glomeruli.
  • Histopathologically, light microscopy reveals swollen glomeruli filled with inflammatory cells such as neutrophils and monocytes, accompanied by proliferation of mesangial and endothelial components, and sometimes crescent formation.
  • Immunofluorescence shows granular immune deposits composed of IgG and C3, and occasionally IgM which is distributed within the mesangium and along the glomerular basement membrane.
  • Electron microscopy characteristically reveals subepithelial electron-dense "hump-like" deposits, and may also show deposits in subendothelial, mesangial, or intramembranous locations.
  • Clinically, children often exhibit fatigue, fever, nausea, oliguria, cola-colored urine, periorbital puffiness, hematuria, mild proteinuria, and elevated blood pressure.
  • While the overall prognosis is favorable with supportive care, a small percentage of cases may progress to a more aggressive, rapidly deteriorating form.

Explanation of other options:

Dense deposit disease (Option B): Dense deposit disease (formerly membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type II) is a glomerular disorder caused by excessive activation of the alternative complement pathway, leading to C3 deposition. Decreased levels of serum C3, with normal C1 and C4, and reduced Factor B and properdin is seen. Electron microscopy reveals ribbon-like, electron-dense material within the lamina densa of the glomerular basement membrane. Immunofluorescence shows granular or linear C3 in the basement membrane and circular mesangial C3 aggregates but IgG deposits are never seen. Histologically, patterns range from mesangial proliferative to crescentic.

Goodpasture syndrome (Option C): An autoimmune disorder marked by circulating antibodies targeting the α3 chain of collagen IV in the glomerular and alveolar basement membranes, leading to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage, most commonly in young male smokers. Pulmonary symptoms such as hemoptysis precede renal involvement, which progresses to crescentic glomerulonephritis and renal failure. Histology reveals linear IgG and complement deposits along basement membranes.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option D): One of the leading causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults. The hallmark feature under light microscopy is focal (affecting some but not all glomeruli) and segmental (limited to segments of individual glomeruli) sclerosis involving only a subset of glomeruli, which can be missed if sampling is inadequate. On electron microscopy, a characteristic finding is the diffuse effacement of foot processes. Additional features include hyalinosis, thickening of afferent arterioles, and eventually global sclerosis with tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man complains of nasal obstruction, bloody nose, cough, and bloody sputum. A chest X-ray shows cavitatory lesions and multiple nodules within both lung fields. Urine analysis reveals 3+ hematuria and red blood cell casts. Laboratory studies elevated serum levels of c-ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody). A renal biopsy was performed and histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario points to a case of granulomatosis with polyangiitis which along with crescents on light microscopy of kidney biopsy suggests a diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical syndrome marked by rapid loss of kidney function and severe glomerular injury usually seen in the setting of nephritic syndrome symptoms such as hematuria, oliguria, azotemia, and hypertension.
  • The hallmark histologic feature is crescent formation in the glomeruli due to proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltration of monocytes and macrophages into Bowman's space.
  • Based on immunopathology, RPGN is classified into three types:
    • Type I (anti-GBM antibody mediated), which may be associated with pulmonary hemorrhage as seen in Goodpasture syndrome.
    • Type II (immune complex mediated), linked to postinfectious GN, lupus nephritis, or IgA nephropathy.
    • Type III (pauci-immune), typically ANCA-associated, such as in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously Wegener's granulomatosis) or microscopic polyangiitis.
  • Pauci-immune RPGN has no significant immune deposits on immunofluorescence or EM, but patients often have circulating PR3-ANCA (c-ANCA) or MPO-ANCA (p-ANCA).
  • Morphologically, the kidneys are enlarged and pale with petechial hemorrhages, and microscopy shows segmental necrosis, endothelial and mesangial proliferation, fibrin strands in crescents, and glomerular basement membrane ruptures.
  • Depending on the underlying cause, immunofluorescence shows linear deposits (Goodpasture), granular deposits (immune complex type), or no deposits (pauci-immune).
  • Without treatment, RPGN rapidly progresses to renal failure.
  • Early therapy with steroids, cytotoxic agents, and plasmapheresis can restore renal function, especially in Goodpasture syndrome, but late diagnosis often leads to ESRD requiring dialysis or transplant.

Explanation of other options:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option A): Emerges a few weeks after streptococcal infection and is characterized by immune complex-mediated glomerular inflammation. Histologically, the glomeruli appear enlarged and hypercellular due to infiltration by neutrophils and monocytes, along with proliferation of mesangial and endothelial cells, and in some instances, crescents may be present. Most cases respond well to conservative treatment, though a small subset may evolve into rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type I (Option C): MPGN Type I is characterized by immune complex deposits composed of IgG and complement components and the glomeruli are typically large and hypercellular due to mesangial and endocapillary proliferation, giving rise to a lobular appearance with increased mesangial matrix and thickened GBM. A characteristic "double-contour" or "tram-track" appearance is seen especially on silver and PAS stains. It results from basement membrane duplication around subendothelial immune deposits, with frequent crescent formation.

Membranous nephropathy (Option D): Membranous nephropathy typically presents insidiously with features of nephrotic syndrome, including heavy proteinuria, generalized edema, and hyperlipidemia. Most cases are idiopathic, though some arise secondary to triggers like specific drugs, infections, malignancies, autoimmune diseases, or systemic illnesses. On light microscopy, glomeruli may look unremarkable in the initial phases of the disease or may show a consistent, widespread thickening of the capillary walls. Subepithelial immune complex deposits that prompt the formation of characteristic spike-like projections from the glomerular basement membrane can be seen on electron microscopy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complains of recurrent hematuria since his youth. The hematuria typically occurs following upper respiratory tract infections. Vital signs are normal. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, hematuria, and a few red blood cell casts. Laboratory studies disclose normal levels of BUN and creatinine. The ANA and ANCA tests are negative. Which of the characteristic findings that leads to diagnosis of disease is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette of recurrent hematuria after upper respiratory tract infection is suggestive of IgA nephropathy which is characterised by IgA deposition in the mesangium.

  • IgA nephropathy, also called Berger disease, is defined by the accumulation of IgA, primarily IgA1, in the mesangium of glomeruli, often presenting with visible hematuria that follows respiratory or gastrointestinal infections. (Options A, B, and C ruled out)
  • This condition can occur as an isolated renal disease or as part of systemic diseases such as Henoch-Schonlein purpura, or secondary to hepatic or intestinal disorders.
  • The pathogenesis follows a "multi-hit" hypothesis, beginning with excessive production of abnormally glycosylated polymeric IgA1, which is poorly cleared and prompts the formation of immune complexes.
  • These are either directly deposited or formed in situ in the mesangium, where they activate mesangial cells, prompting cytokine release, cell proliferation, and matrix expansion, leading to glomerular damage.
  • Immunofluorescence typically reveals mesangial IgA and C3, sometimes with IgG or IgM, and electron microscopy confirms electron-dense mesangial deposits.
  • Lesions seen on histology may vary from normal to mesangioproliferative, focal proliferative, or even crescentic GN, with mesangial widening due to proliferation or deposits.
  • Clinically, it affects all ages, especially children and young adults, with recurrent macroscopic or microscopic hematuria, occasionally developing into acute nephritic syndrome or progressing to chronic kidney failure.
  • Risk factors for progression include older age, proteinuria, hypertension, and glomerulosclerosis. Recurrence after kidney transplantation is common, and in some cases, follows a similar slow progressive course.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presented with facial puffiness. Physical examination revealed edema. Laboratory findings revealed creatinine of 3.8 mg/dL along with proteinuria. A differential diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome was made. All of these metabolic findings will be seen in this patient; except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nephrotic syndrome is characterised by hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and loss of anticoagulants but not loss of fibrinogen.

  • Nephrotic syndrome is a clinical condition marked by increased glomerular capillary wall permeability leading to massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, hyperlipidemia, and lipiduria, commonly caused by both primary renal and systemic diseases. (Options A and B ruled out)
  • Clinical features of nephrotic and nephritic syndrome are summarised as below:
  • It occurs due to structural or functional alterations in the glomerular filtration barrier, comprising the endothelium, basement membrane, and podocytes, allowing plasma proteins, particularly albumin, to leak into the urine.
  • This excessive protein loss results in hypoalbuminemia, which reduces plasma oncotic pressure and causes generalized edema, often accompanied by sodium and water retention.
  • Patients typically show massive proteinuria (≥3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia (<3 g/dL), and lipid abnormalities, including elevated cholesterol and triglycerides, due to both increased hepatic synthesis and impaired catabolism.
  • Lipids also leak into urine, resulting in lipiduria and fatty casts or oval fat bodies are visible under microscopy.
  • Because of the protein losses, especially immunoglobulins and complement factors, nephrotic patients are more prone to infections and thromboembolic events like renal vein thrombosis, particularly due to the loss of anticoagulants such as antithrombin III. (Option C ruled out)
  • The pathogenesis varies with age: in children, primary renal lesions are predominant, such as minimal change disease while adults often have systemic causes like diabetes mellitus, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), or amyloidosis.
  • Among primary glomerular diseases, the leading causes are minimal change disease, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), and membranous nephropathy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with facial puffiness along with pedal edema for 3 weeks. Physical examination shows pitting edema. Laboratory examination shows normal CBC, LFT but deranged KFT. Urinary examination revealed proteinuria 3+, no RBC or WBC is seen. Renal biopsy performed is as shown below. Based on these findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of nephrotic syndrome in a child along with normal light microscopy findings on kidney biopsy suggests a diagnosis of minimal change disease.

  • Minimal change disease is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome, especially in children aged 2 to 6, and is characterized by the effacement of podocyte foot processes, which is only detectable under electron microscopy as shown below since glomeruli appear normal on light microscopy.
  • Its pathogenesis is thought to involve immune dysfunction, likely triggered by infections, immunizations, or associated with atopic conditions and Hodgkin lymphoma,
  • It is marked by the absence of immune complex deposition and possibly involves T-cell mediated mechanisms or circulating permeability factors like angiopoietin-like-4.
  • Morphologically, electron microscopy reveals uniform podocyte foot process effacement with no immune deposits, while immunofluorescence is negative for Ig or complement, and proximal tubules may show lipid and protein reabsorption, giving the term "lipid nephrosis."
  • Clinically, despite marked proteinuria (mainly albumin), patients usually maintain normal renal function without hypertension or hematuria, and the condition typically responds dramatically to corticosteroids in children, with excellent long-term outcomes even in steroid-dependent or resistant cases.
  • In adults, the disease may be slower to respond and can be associated with Hodgkin lymphoma, other hematologic malignancies, or NSAID use; in both age groups, the prognosis remains favorable with appropriate therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option A): Typically develops several weeks following a streptococcal infection and is driven by immune complex deposition that provokes glomerular inflammation. Microscopically, affected glomeruli are enlarged and densely cellular, reflecting mesangial and endothelial proliferation alongside infiltration by neutrophils and monocytes; in some cases, crescent formation is also observed.

Crescentic glomerulonephritis (Option B): Rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis (RPGN) refers to a clinical syndrome characterized by a sudden and steadily worsening loss of kidney function resulting from intense glomerular damage, typically accompanied by crescent formation in the glomeruli.

Membranous nephropathy (Option D): Membranous nephropathy typically has an insidious onset, presenting with features of nephrotic syndrome including heavy proteinuria, generalized edema, and hyperlipidemia. Most cases are idiopathic, but some arise secondarily due to drugs, infections, malignancies, autoimmune conditions, or systemic illnesses. Light microscopy may reveal widespread thickening of the glomerular capillary walls due to immunoglobulin deposition which can be seen as subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy.

choices.text: Immunofluorescence shows no immunoglobulin or complement deposition
Electron microscopy shows electron dense material deposition in mesangium
Electron microscopy shows effacement of foot process of visceral epithelial cells

questions.text: A 12-year-old male child presented with facial puffiness along with pedal edema for 3 weeks. Physical examination shows pitting edema. Laboratory examination shows normal CBC, LFT but deranged KFT. Urinary examination revealed proteinuria 3+, no RBC or WBC seen. Renal biopsy performed shown below. All of the following statements are true regarding the diagnosis, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is minimal change disease and the false statement regarding the condition is - "electron microscopy shows electron dense material deposition in mesangium".

  • Minimal change disease is a frequent cause of nephrotic syndrome, predominantly affecting children between 2 and 6 years of age.
  • It is defined by the flattening or fusion of podocyte foot processes, a change only visible under electron microscopy, since light microscopy usually shows normal glomeruli. (Options A and D ruled out)
  • The disorder is believed to be immune-related, possibly initiated by infections, vaccines, or linked to allergic conditions and Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • There is no immune complex deposition, and the underlying mechanism may involve T-cell dysfunction or circulating factors such as angiopoietin-like-4 that increase glomerular permeability.
  • On electron microscopy, presence of lipid and protein droplets in proximal tubules, features collectively referred to as "lipid nephrosis" is noted. There is absence of immune deposits.
  • Immunofluorescence studies are typically negative for immunoglobulins and complement. (Option B ruled out)
  • Clinically, the disease is characterized by heavy albuminuria but preserved renal function, with no accompanying hematuria or hypertension. In children, it often responds rapidly and completely to steroid therapy.
  • Adult cases may show delayed response and are sometimes associated with underlying conditions like Hodgkin disease or NSAID use. Nonetheless, the overall outlook with treatment remains very good.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient complains of blood in urine. Physical examination revealed raised BP and pitting edema. Laboratory findings like CBC and LFT are normal. Renal function tests are deranged showing raised creatinine and urea. Urinary investigation shows proteinuria 4+. Renal biopsy was performed and is as shown below. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario along with histopathology of renal biopsy showing thickened glomerular capillary membrane without hypercellularity suggests a diagnosis of membranous nephropathy.

  • Membranous nephropathy is a chronic, immune complex-mediated glomerular disease marked by diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall due to subepithelial immune deposits, often idiopathic but sometimes secondary to drugs, infections, malignancies, or autoimmune conditions.
  • It primarily manifests with insidious onset of nephrotic syndrome and about 75% of cases are primary (idiopathic), commonly involving antibodies against renal antigens like PLA2R (M-type phospholipase A2 receptor) or THSD7A.
  • Secondary causes account for the remaining cases and include drugs (e.g., NSAIDs, penicillamine, gold), malignancies (especially of the lung, colon, and melanoma), SLE, chronic infections (e.g., hepatitis B and C, syphilis), and other autoimmune diseases like thyroiditis.
  • Pathogenetically, immune complex deposition, often containing IgG4 and complement (C5b-C9), leads to complement activation and podocyte injury, increasing glomerular permeability.
  • Electron microscopy demonstrates irregular subepithelial electron-dense deposits with intervening spikes of basement membrane material, while immunofluorescence reveals granular deposition of Ig and complement.
  • Silver staining in membranous nephropathy highlights the characteristic "spike and dome" pattern by staining the basement membrane but not the immune deposits, thus helping visualize the protruding basement membrane spikes between subepithelial deposits.
  • Clinically, the disease course is variable and typically unresponsive to corticosteroids. Proteinuria is often nonselective and persistent, and hypertension or microscopic hematuria may occur.

Explanation of other options:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (Option A): Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a classic example of a postinfectious glomerular disease that manifests after a latent period following a streptococcal infection, often of the pharynx or skin. The pathogenesis involves deposition of immune complexes in the glomeruli, which triggers an inflammatory response. Histologically, the glomeruli appear markedly enlarged and hypercellular due to proliferation of both mesangial and endothelial cells. This is compounded by infiltration of inflammatory cells, particularly neutrophils and monocytes.

Crescentic nephritis (Option B): Rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity marked by a swift and continuous decline in renal function due to severe glomerular injury, often associated with the presence of crescents in glomeruli.

Minimal change disease (Option C): Minimal change disease, the most frequent cause of nephrotic syndrome in children aged 2 - 6, is characterized by diffuse podocyte foot process effacement visible only on electron microscopy, with normal glomeruli under light microscopy and absence of immune deposits.
