Immune complex deposits between basement membrane and epithelial cells

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient complains of blood in urine. Physical examination revealed raised BP and pitting edema. Laboratory findings like CBC and LFT are normal. Renal function tests are deranged showing raised creatinine and urea. Urinary investigation shows proteinuria 4+. Renal biopsy was performed, shown below. Based on the diagnosis which of the following will be seen on electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and renal biopsy findings of thickened capillary walls without increased cellularity are consistent with membranous nephropathy and all the mentioned features are seen on electron microscopy.

  • Membranous nephropathy is characterized by uniform thickening of the glomerular capillary walls due to the presence of subepithelial immune complexes, frequently involving autoantibodies like anti-PLA2R or THSD7A in primary forms.
  • Secondary cases arise from exposure to certain medications (such as NSAIDs, penicillamine, gold), infections (like hepatitis B or syphilis), autoimmune disorders (e.g., SLE, thyroiditis), or malignancies (notably lung and colon cancers, and melanoma).
  • The immune complexes, usually IgG4 and components of the membrane attack complex (C5b-C9), cause podocyte damage and increase permeability and are seen as granular deposits on immunofluorescence.
  • On electron microscopy, these deposits appear as subepithelial electron-dense immune deposits interspersed with spikes of basement membrane, giving rise to the "spike and dome" appearance. Effacement of foot processes is also noted.
  • The spike and dome pattern is enhanced by silver staining, which highlights basement membrane projections while leaving the deposits unstained.
  • The immunofluorescence and electron microscopy findings are as shown below.
  • Clinically, patients present with slowly progressing nephrotic syndrome, often showing persistent, nonselective proteinuria, occasional microscopic hematuria, and poor response to corticosteroids.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man complains of swelling of his legs and puffiness of face. Physical examination reveals generalized edema and ascites. Laboratory findings revealed normal CBC and LFT. Renal function tests are deranged with proteinuria of 5g/ 24 hours. The urinary sediment contains many hyaline casts but no RBCs or inflammatory cells. A renal biopsy stained by silver stain, is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of nephrotic syndrome along with silver staining on renal biopsy showing spike and dome appearance points to a diagnosis of membranous nephropathy.

  • In membranous nephropathy, the glomerular capillary walls exhibit uniform thickening due to immune complex deposits beneath the epithelial layer, particularly involving anti-PLA2R or THSD7A antibodies in primary disease.
  • Secondary forms may result from drug exposures (e.g., NSAIDs, gold, penicillamine), chronic infections (hepatitis B, syphilis), autoimmune conditions (like lupus or autoimmune thyroiditis), or malignancies such as lung, colon cancer, and melanoma.
  • These immune complexes, primarily IgG4 and complement components like C5b-C9, induce podocyte injury and compromise the filtration barrier.
  • Electron microscopy reveals dense subepithelial deposits separated by extensions of basement membrane, forming the classic "spike and dome" pattern, accompanied by podocyte foot process effacement.
  • Silver staining accentuates these spikes by coloring the basement membrane while sparing the deposits.
  • Clinically, patients exhibit progressive nephrotic syndrome with ongoing protein loss (often nonselective), occasional hematuria, and resistance to steroid therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type I (Option A): Type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) features IgG and complement immune complex deposition, causing glomerular enlargement, hypercellularity, and basement membrane duplication that produces a distinctive "tram-track" especially on silver or PAS stains.

Minimal change disease (Option C): The leading cause of nephrotic syndrome in young children (ages 2 to 6), is defined by widespread loss of podocyte foot processes detectable only via electron microscopy, while light microscopy shows no abnormalities and immune complexes are absent.

Crescentic nephropathy (Option D): Rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity marked by a swift and continuous decline in renal function due to severe glomerular injury, often associated with the presence of crescents in glomeruli.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient who is a drug abuser presented with complaints of gradually increasing swelling over the leg and puffiness of face. Investigations revealed hematuria and mild hypertension. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. Renal biopsy performed is as shown below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario of nephrotic syndrome and histopathology showing focal and segmental involvement of glomeruli is suggestive of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a podocytopathy marked by sclerosis of segments of some glomeruli, presenting with nephrotic syndrome (especially in adults), showing poor steroid responsiveness, a risk of progression to renal failure, and diverse underlying causes ranging from idiopathic to genetic, adaptive, infectious, or drug-related.
  • It is defined histologically by sclerosis that affects parts (segmental) of some (focal) glomeruli. Podocyte injury, with effacement of foot processes, is the ultrastructural hallmark, making it similar in pathogenesis to minimal change disease, but more severe.
  • The sclerosis reflects trapping of plasma proteins in hyperpermeable areas and accumulation of extracellular matrix. The sclerotic segments also show collapse of capillary loops.
  • This can arise as a primary (idiopathic) condition or be secondary to conditions like HIV (especially the collapsing variant), heroin use, obesity, sickle cell disease, or maladaptive responses to nephron loss.
  • Genetically, mutations in slit diaphragm proteins like nephrin (NPHS1), podocin (NPHS2), TRPC6, and others are implicated in hereditary forms.
  • Electron microscopy confirms podocyte injury with diffuse effacement of foot processes, and immunofluorescence may show nonspecific trapping of IgM and C3 in sclerotic areas.

Explanation of other options:

Crescentic nephropathy (Option A): Rapidly progressive (crescentic) glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity marked by a swift and continuous decline in renal function due to severe glomerular injury, often associated with the presence of crescents in glomeruli.

Membranous nephropathy (Option B): Commonly begins gradually with signs of nephrotic syndrome such as pronounced protein loss, body swelling, and elevated lipid levels, and while often idiopathic, it may also result from secondary causes like certain medications, infections, cancers, or autoimmune disorders. On histopathological examination, the capillary walls of glomeruli appear diffusely thickened under light microscopy due to the presence of immunoglobulin-containing immune complexes. Electron microscopy confirms this by revealing subepithelial electron-dense deposits along the basement membrane.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type I (Option D): Type I MPGN is marked by immune complex deposits containing IgG and complement, leading to enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli and duplication of the basement membrane that produces a characteristic "tram-track" appearance, particularly evident on PAS or silver staining.

choices.text: Light microscopy shows focal and segmental sclerosis of the glomeruli
Sclerotic region shows increase matrix and collapse of capillary
Immunofluorescence study shows deposition of IgG, IgA and C3 in sclerotic area and/or in mesangium
Electron microscopy shows diffuse effacement of foot process in sclerotic and nonsclerotic area

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presented with a 4-month history of progressive swelling in his ankles and abdomen. Urinalysis shows heavy proteinuria (>4 g per 24 hours) but no evidence of inflammatory cells or RBCs. Laboratory studies reveal hyperlipidemia and hypoalbuminemia. Serum creatinine level is normal. The patient responds well to treatment with corticosteroids, but edema and proteinuria recur the following year. The steroid treatment is repeated with the same results. Upon the third recurrence of edema and proteinuria, the patient becomes steroid resistant. A renal biopsy is shown in the image. All of following statements are true regarding the diagnosis; except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • By light microscopy, the focal and segmental lesions may involve only a minority of the glomeruli and may be missed, if the biopsy specimen contains an insufficient number of glomeruli.
  • In the sclerotic segments, there is collapse of capillary loops, increase in matrix, and segmental deposition of plasma proteins along the capillary wall (hyalinosis), which may become so pronounced as to occlude capillary lumens.
  • By immunofluorescence microscopy, IgM and C3 may be present in the sclerotic areas and/or in the mesangium.
  • On electron microscopy, both sclerotic and nonsclerotic areas show diffuse effacement of foot processes, and there may also be focal detachment of the epithelial cells and denudation of the underlying GBM.

choices.text: Histology will show proliferation of mesangial cells and mesangial matrix
Silver stain will show duplication of basement membrane
Immunofluorescence shows IgM and C4 deposition in a granular pattern
Electron microscopy shows sub endothelial deposits

questions.text: A 12-year-old male patient presented with puffiness of face, swelling in the feet and hematuria for 3 months. Laboratory studies show elevated serum levels of creatinine and BUN. Urinalysis reveals 3+ proteinuria and presence of RBCs. The renal biopsy was performed and the image is as shown below. All of the following statements are true regarding the diagnosis, except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario along with light microscopy of renal biopsy showing enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with lobular appearance is suggestive of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) and immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 deposition in a granular pattern.

  • MPGN is a morphologic pattern of immune-mediated glomerular injury and includes two major types: type I (immune complex-mediated) and type II (dense deposit disease), both showing mesangial and endocapillary proliferation with basement membrane duplication. The latter is characterized by complement activation via the alternative pathway without immunoglobulin deposition.
  • Histologically, MPGN type I presents with large, hypercellular glomeruli due to mesangial and endocapillary proliferation, mesangial matrix expansion, and lobular accentuation. (Option A ruled out)
  • A key diagnostic hallmark is the "double contour" or "tram-track" appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), attributed to its duplication around subendothelial immune complexes, best appreciated with silver or PAS stains as shown below. (Option B ruled out)
  • In type I, IgG, C3, and early complement components (C1q, C4) are found on immunofluorescence, and electron microscopy reveals discrete subendothelial electron-dense deposits. (Option D ruled out)
  • Type II disease is associated with deposition of a ribbon-like, dense material in the lamina densa of the GBM, best seen on electron microscopy.
  • C3 is found in a granular or linear pattern, but IgG and classical complement components are absent.
  • Most dense deposit disease patients possess C3 nephritic factor (C3NeF), an autoantibody that stabilizes the C3 convertase, leading to persistent activation and hypocomplementemia.
  • MPGN can be idiopathic or secondary to infections (like hepatitis B or C), autoimmune diseases (such as SLE), and malignancies (especially lymphoid).
  • Clinically, it affects adolescents and young adults, presenting with nephritic or nephrotic syndrome, or both.
  • The prognosis is guarded, especially in dense deposit disease, with a high risk of recurrence post-transplantation and over half progressing to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) within 10 years.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male patient presented with puffiness of face, swelling in the feet and hematuria since 3 months. Laboratory studies show elevated serum levels of creatinine and BUN. Urinalysis reveals 3+ proteinuria and presence of RBCs. The renal biopsy along with silver stain performed. The image of silver stain is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The GBM is thickened, and often shows a "doublecontour" or "tramtrack" appearance, especially evident in silver or PAS stains. This is caused by "duplication" of the basement membrane (also commonly referred to as splitting), usually as the result of new basement membrane synthesis in response to subendothelial deposits of immune complexes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman complained of severe headaches and dizziness. The patient has a history of repeated urinary tract infections. The blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show elevated levels of BUN (38 mg/dL) and creatinine (2.8 mg/dL). A CT scan of the lower abdomen reveals small, irregularly shaped kidneys with deep coarse scars. Nephrectomy was done and histopathological examination features are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette along with CT scan revealing shrunken scarred kidneys and histopathological examination showing thyroidization of tubules points to a diagnosis of chronic pyelonephritis.

  • Chronic pyelonephritis is a renal disorder marked by persistent tubulointerstitial inflammation and fibrosis that specifically affects the renal calyces and pelvis.
  • It may arise silently or present with symptoms of recurrent urinary tract infections, including fever, back pain, and pyuria, often in the context of urinary tract anomalies such as reflux nephropathy.
  • Grossly, kidneys affected by CPN display irregular, asymmetric scarring, predominantly at the upper and lower poles.
  • Classic lesions include coarse, well-demarcated corticomedullary scars overlying dilated and deformed calyces, with papillary flattening.
  • Microscopic features primarily involve tubular and interstitial changes, with dilated tubules resembling thyroid follicles (thyroidization) as shown below, atrophy, fibrosis, and chronic inflammatory infiltrates
  • Although glomeruli may appear relatively preserved, they can show ischemic alterations, and late-stage disease may develop into secondary FSGS with associated proteinuria.
  • Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is a rare subtype characterized by an accumulation of foamy macrophages and mixed inflammatory cells, often linked to Proteus infection and urinary obstruction, producing yellow nodules that may mimic renal tumors.
  • Clinically, CPN can lead to gradual renal insufficiency and hypertension, with late discovery due to its insidious progression. Reflux nephropathy, especially in children, often manifests during hypertension evaluation. Impaired tubular function can result in polyuria and nocturia.
  • Imaging typically reveals small, asymmetrically contracted kidneys with blunted calyces.

Explanation of other options:

Acute pyelonephritis (Option A): Both acute and chronic pyelonephritis commonly result from ascending bacterial infections, especially when there is urinary tract obstruction or reflux. Acute pyelonephritis is histologically marked by patchy interstitial suppurative inflammation, intratubular neutrophilic aggregates, neutrophilic tubulitis, and tubular injury. In its early phase, neutrophilic infiltration is primarily confined to tubules, but may spread to the interstitium, leading to abscess formation and destruction of involved tubules. Glomeruli are generally spared unless the infection is severe or fungal in origin (e.g., Candida), which may produce granulomatous inflammation.

Acute tubular necrosis (Option B): Now more accurately termed acute tubular injury (ATI), is marked by acute renal failure with patchy necrosis or injury of tubular epithelial cells, commonly caused by ischemia or direct toxicity. ATI presents histologically with tubular epithelial damage at multiple sites along the nephron, with intervening normal areas, rupture of basement membranes (tubulorrhexis), and obstruction of tubule lumens by proteinaceous casts.

Tubulointerstitial nephritis (Option D): Refers to renal disorders marked by inflammation and injury of the tubules and interstitium, typically presenting with insidious onset and azotemia. It can be acute, showing interstitial edema and neutrophilic infiltration, or chronic, featuring mononuclear inflammation, interstitial fibrosis, and tubular atrophy. These conditions are clinically distinguished from glomerular diseases by the absence of nephritic/nephrotic features and the presence of tubular dysfunction, such as impaired concentration, acid excretion, or salt reabsorption.

questions.text: Which of the following areas in a kidney is usually spared in early pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glomeruli is spared in early pyelonephritis.

  • Acute pyelonephritis is a bacterial, and occasionally viral, infection of the kidney characterized by a suppurative inflammatory response, often ascending from the lower urinary tract and frequently associated with vesicoureteral reflux.
  • Morphologically, it shows patchy interstitial neutrophilic inflammation, tubular injury, and intratubular aggregates of neutrophils, sometimes forming abscesses and wedge-shaped areas of necrosis.
  • Initially, neutrophils infiltrate only the tubules, which act as channels for the infection to spread. As the disease progresses, the infection can reach the interstitium, leading to abscess formation and destruction of the affected tubules. While glomeruli are typically spared in early stages, severe or widespread infection may eventually involve and damage them. (Options B and C ruled out)
  • Fungal infections like Candida-related pyelonephritis frequently induce granulomatous inflammation in the interstitial tissue.
  • Complications such as papillary necrosis, pyonephrosis (due to obstructive pus accumulation), and perinephric abscess may occur, particularly in diabetics or those with urinary tract obstruction.
  • Clinically, acute pyelonephritis is linked to urinary tract obstruction, catheterization, reflux, pregnancy, preexisting renal lesions, diabetes, and immunosuppression.
  • It manifests with sudden costovertebral angle pain, fever, malaise, and urinary symptoms like dysuria and urgency.
  • Pyuria is present but not diagnostic of upper tract involvement. However, leukocyte casts confirm renal origin of infection.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by quantitative urine culture. Most cases resolve rapidly with antibiotics, though bacteria may persist or reinfect with a different serotype.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with complaints of hematuria. He is also diagnosed with polycythemia. An enlarged right kidney is found on X-ray examination, and CT scan reveals a renal mass of irregular shape, measuring 6 cm in diameter. Nephrectomy was done and sent for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of hematuria, microcytic hypochromic anemia, and histopathological examination showing rounded and polygonal clear cells points to a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma.

  • Renal cell carcinoma has a male predominance (2:1) and peak incidence in the sixth to seventh decades of life.
  • Tobacco use is the most important risk factor, doubling the incidence, with additional associations including obesity, hypertension, estrogen therapy, asbestos exposure, and some hereditary syndromes such as von Hippel-Lindau (VHL), hereditary leiomyomatosis, hereditary papillary carcinoma, and Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome.
  • VHL syndrome, in particular, is strongly linked to clear cell RCC and involves mutations in the VHL gene on chromosome 3 which, when inactivated, leads to inappropriate activation of HIF-1, promoting angiogenesis and cell growth.
  • Clear cell carcinoma, the most prevalent subtype, typically presents as a solitary, yellow-gray, spherical cortical mass with lipid accumulation, hemorrhage, necrosis, and sharply demarcated margins.
  • Histologically, the tumors display cells with clear or granular cytoplasm and are often sporadic, although they can be familial.
  • Genetic alterations include deletions on chromosome 3p involving the VHL gene, and somatic mutations or epigenetic inactivation of the second allele. Tumor growth distorts the kidney outline and may extend into renal veins and the inferior vena cava.
  • Other subtypes include papillary carcinoma, characterized by architecture and associated with trisomies of chromosomes 7 and 17, chromophobe carcinoma with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halos, Xp11 translocation carcinoma, and collecting duct carcinoma arising from medullary ducts.
  • Clinically, RCCs may be asymptomatic or present with classic signs such as hematuria, flank pain, and palpable mass, though all three occur in only a minority.
  • Systemic symptoms like fever and weight loss are common, and paraneoplastic syndromes such as polycythemia, hypercalcemia, hypertension, or hepatic dysfunction can occur due to ectopic hormone production.
  • Many tumors are now detected incidentally via imaging before symptoms appear. RCC is known for mimicking other systemic illnesses due to its diverse presentations.

Explanation of other options:

Angiomyolipoma (Option A): A benign renal tumor composed of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and fat derived from perivascular epithelioid cells. It is associated with tuberous sclerosis. The main clinical concern with angiomyolipomas is their tendency to bleed spontaneously, which can be life-threatening.

Oncocytoma (Option B): A benign epithelial tumor that originates from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts and s composed of large eosinophilic cells with small, round nuclei and prominent nucleoli, which contain abundant mitochondria. Grossly, these tumors are tan to mahogany brown, well-circumscribed, and often exhibit a central stellate scar in roughly one-third of cases.

Wilm's tumor (Option D): Also called nephroblastoma, is the most frequent primary renal tumor in children. Histologically, Wilms tumor displays a triphasic pattern made up of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial elements, though the proportion of each can vary. Grossly, it is seen as a large, well-circumscribed mass that may show hemorrhage, cysts, or necrosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presented with complaints of hematuria. He is otherwise in excellent health, except for a microcytic, hypochromic anemia. An enlarged right kidney is found on X-ray examination, and CT scan reveals a renal mass of irregular shape, measuring 6 cm in diameter. Nephrectomy was done and sent for histopathological examination which shows clear cell carcinoma (image shown). Which gene is most commonly mutated in this tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Current studies implicate the VHL gene is most commonly involved in the development of both familial and sporadic clear cell carcinomas.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presented with complaints of hematuria. An enlarged right kidney is found on X-ray examination, and CT scan reveals a renal mass of irregular shape, measuring 6 cm in diameter. Nephrectomy was done and sent for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario along with histopathological image showing cells with prominent cell membranes and eosinophilic cytoplasm suggests a diagnosis of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma.

  • Renal cell carcinoma is associated with a higher incidence in males (2:1), typically affecting individuals in their 60s and 70s.
  • Cigarette smoking is the most significant risk factor, doubling the risk, with other contributing factors including obesity, hypertension, unopposed estrogen therapy, and certain toxins like petroleum products, asbestos, and heavy metals.
  • Most RCCs are sporadic, but familial syndromes such as Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL), hereditary leiomyomatosis, hereditary papillary carcinoma, Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome, and others.
  • Chromophobe carcinoma accounts for about 5% of renal cell carcinomas and is made up of cells that have distinct cell borders and pale, eosinophilic cytoplasm, often featuring a clear area surrounding the nucleus. Cytogenetically, these tumors exhibit extensive chromosomal loss and significant hypodiploidy. They are believed to arise from the intercalated cells of the collecting ducts. However, it can be difficult to differentiate them histologically from oncocytomas.
  • Renal cell carcinoma typically presents with the classic triad of costovertebral pain, a palpable mass, and hematuria, though all three occur together in only about 10% of patients.
  • It is also associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as polycythemia, hypercalcemia, hypertension, feminization or masculinization, Cushing syndrome, eosinophilia, leukemoid reactions, and amyloidosis.
  • A major concern is its early hematogenous spread, especially to lungs, bones, and lymph nodes, with metastases found in 15% of cases at diagnosis.
  • Treatment includes nephron-sparing surgery for smaller tumors, radical nephrectomy for larger ones, and targeted therapies (e.g., VEGF and tyrosine kinase inhibitors) for metastatic disease.

Explanation of other options:

Clear cell carcinoma (Option A): The most prevalent subtype of renal cell carcinoma characterized histologically by tumor cells with clear or granular cytoplasm as shown below. Most cases are sporadic, though some are linked to VHL gene alterations, particularly deletions on chromosome 3p.

Papillary carcinoma (Option B): Papillary carcinoma is characterised by a papillary growth architecture. It occurs in both sporadic and familial forms and is associated with cytogenetic abnormalities such as trisomies 7 and 17, and loss of the Y chromosome in males. Familial forms involve MET gene mutations on chromosome 7. These tumors are often multifocal and involve hepatocyte growth factor signaling.

Oncocytoma (Option D): Oncocytoma is a benign epithelial tumor that makes up 5-15% of renal neoplasms and arises from the intercalated cells of collecting ducts. Histologically, it features large eosinophilic cells with small round nuclei and prominent nucleoli, as shown below. Grossly, the tumor appears tan to mahogany brown, is well encapsulated, often with a central stellate scar, and may grow up to 12 cm in diameter; some familial cases show multicentricity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with complaints of hematuria. An enlarged right kidney is found on X-ray examination, and CT scan reveals a renal mass of irregular shape, measuring 6 cm in diameter. After nephrectomy, the tumor is found to be encapsulated, mahogany brown in color and have a central scar and sent for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given history along with histopathology showing eosinophilic cells with round prominent nucleoli points to a diagnosis of oncocytoma.

  • Oncocytoma is a benign epithelial tumor composed of large eosinophilic cells that have small, round, non-atypical nuclei with prominent nucleoli.
  • It is believed to originate from intercalated cells of the collecting ducts and the cells are rich in mitochondria when viewed ultrastructurally.
  • Grossly, oncocytomas appear tan or mahogany brown, are fairly uniform, and are typically well circumscribed with a central stellate scar seen in roughly one-third of cases.
  • These tumors can grow significantly, reaching up to 12 cm in diameter, and in some familial cases, they can be multicentric rather than solitary.

Explanation of other options:

Clear cell carcinoma (Option A): The most common form of renal cell carcinoma characterised histologically by the presence of tumor cells with clear or granular cytoplasm, as illustrated below. While the majority of cases occur sporadically, a subset is associated with alterations in the VHL gene, especially deletions on the short arm of chromosome 3.

Angiomyolipoma (Option B): Angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor composed of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and fat derived from perivascular epithelioid cells. It is associated with tuberous sclerosis, a condition caused by mutations in the TSC1 or TSC2 genes that leads to neurological symptoms and benign growths in multiple organs. The main clinical concern with angiomyolipomas is their tendency to undergo spontaneous bleeding. Histopathology is as shown below.

Papillary renal cell carcinoma (Option D): Papillary carcinoma displays a papillary structural pattern and can arise in both inherited and non-inherited forms. It commonly shows chromosomal changes like trisomy 7 and 17, along with Y chromosome loss in males. Inherited cases are linked to mutations in the MET gene located on chromosome 7. These tumors frequently appear at multiple sites and involve pathways related to hepatocyte growth factor.

questions.text: A 26-year-old patient presented with sudden onset hematuria. Routine urine microscopy also reveals proteinuria and lab investigations reveal elevated creatinine. PAS stain of renal biopsy is as shown below.. Which of the following cannot be a possible etiology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathology image depicts crescents which along with the history points to a diagnosis of rapidly proliferative glomerulonephritis (RPGN) which is not caused by polyarteritis nodosa.

  • RPGN is a clinical syndrome marked by severe glomerular injury and rapid decline in renal function over days to weeks, commonly presenting with oliguria, hematuria, and nephritic features.
  • The hallmark histological feature is the presence of crescents due to the proliferation of parietal epithelial cells and infiltrating leukocytes within Bowman's space, often leading to glomerular tuft compression and segmental necrosis.
  • There are three types of RPGN and the associated causes as given below.

ANCA = Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies;

GBM = Glomerular basement membrane.

  • Kidneys typically appear enlarged and pale, with crescents forming due to fibrin, cytokine leakage, and epithelial proliferation.
  • Immunofluorescence and electron microscopy reveal linear (anti-GBM), granular (immune complex), or absent (pauci-immune) deposits.
  • Prompt treatment with steroids, cytotoxics, and plasmapheresis (especially in anti-GBM disease) is essential. Delayed diagnosis may result in irreversible renal failure requiring dialysis or transplant.

choices.text: Antibody to alpha 3 chain of type 4 collagen part of non-collagenous domain is responsible
Strong association with HLA DR B1
More commonly seen in young smokers seen
Dense depositions below podocytes are seen in electron microscopy

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with complaints of hematuria, severe hypertension and mild facial puffiness with occasional hemoptysis. The direct immunofluorescence picture of the patient is as given below. Which of the following is not true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is Goodpasture syndrome and the false statement regarding it is "dense depositions below podocytes are seen in electron microscopy"

  • Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune condition involving the kidneys and lungs, caused by antibodies targeting the noncollagenous domain of the α3 chain of collagen IV, leading to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. (Option A ruled out)
  • The α3 chain of type IV collagen is found in glomerular and pulmonary basement membranes.
  • When only renal tissue is affected, it is termed anti-glomerular basement membrane disease, but the full syndrome includes pulmonary involvement, present in 40 -60% of cases.
  • On electron microscopy of renal biopsy, rupture of glomerular basement membrane as seen in all rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis can be seen as shown below.
  • It most often affects young men, particularly smokers. (Option C ruled out)
  • Immunopathogenesis involves antibody-mediated inflammation and necrosis of glomeruli and alveoli, with evidence implicating autoreactive B and T cells, and certain HLA subtypes (e.g., HLA-DRB1\*1501). (Option B ruled out)
  • Morphologically, lungs show red-brown consolidation with alveolar hemorrhage and hemosiderin-laden macrophages, while kidneys exhibit focal proliferative or crescentic glomerulonephritis with linear immunoglobulin and complement deposition on immunofluorescence.
  • Clinically, patients present with hemoptysis and respiratory findings, soon followed by severe renal dysfunction.
  • Death is commonly due to uremia, though prognosis has improved with plasmapheresis and immunosuppressive therapy, which reduce antibody levels and inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following patterns of immune complex deposition is seen by immunofluorescent microscopy in good pasture syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Immunofluorescence studies reveal the characteristic strong linear staining with IgG and C3 along the GBM in anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease, a granular pattern of glomerular staining in immune complex-mediated GN, while in pauci-immune GN the stains are negative.
  • Electron microscopy shows electron dense immune complex deposits within the glomeruli in immune complex-mediated GN, but not in biopsies from those with anti-GBM and pauci-immune crescentic GN.

questions.text: Renal cell Carcinoma is associated with following genetic defects EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The familial variants of renal cell carcinomas are:

  1. Von Hipple landau (VHL) syndrome
  2. Hereditory leiomyomatosis
  3. Hereditary papillary carcinomas
  4. Birt hogg dube syndrome

Hemihypertrophy, also referred to as hemihyperplasia, is a condition in which one side of the body or a part of one side of the body is larger than the other. hemihypertrophy is related to several congenital syndromes including beckwith-wiedemann syndrome and russell-silver syndrome.

choices.text: IgG positivity with a granular pattern
IgG and IgM positivity with a granular pattern
IgG positivity with a linear pattern

questions.text: Which of the following would immunofluorescence staining of the kidney with Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis most likely reveal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • FSGS has entrapped IgM and C3 noted by immunofluorescence staining. IgG positivity with a granular pattern is seen in membranous glomerulonephropathy, IgG and IgM positivity in postinfectious glomerulonephritis, and IgG positivity with a linear pattern in type I rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. IgM positivity with a linear pattern is not normally described in diseases of the kidney.

questions.text: Of the following, serolotic testing for what agent is most likely to be positive in a patient with membranous nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Membranous glomerulonephropathy can be secondarily associated with a variety of conditions, including drug use (NSAIDs), autoimmune disorders (SLE), and various types of cancer and infections; however, the infection most commonly associated with membranous glomerulonephropathy is hepatitis B. Given the results of the biopsy, focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is not the diagnosis, and the chance of a collapsing variant of FSGS associated with HIV infection is less.
  • The other organisms listed are not commonly associated with membranous glomerulonephropathy. It occurs secondary to other conditions, including the following
  • Infections (chronic hepatitis B, syphilis, schistosomiasis, malaria)
  • Malignant neoplasms, particularly carcinoma of the lung and colon and melanoma
  • Autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Exposure to inorganic salts (gold, mercury)
  • Drugs (penicillamine, captopril, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory agents).

questions.text: Urine examination of a patient diagnosed with acute tubular necrosis is shown below. Which among the following is it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Granular casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis.

  • Acute tubular injury (ATI) is a reversible cause of acute kidney injury characterized by damage to tubular epithelial cells, resulting in reduced renal function, commonly due to ischemia or nephrotoxins.
  • It is marked by decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), oliguria (urine output <400 mL/day), and elevated serum creatinine.
  • It is commonly associated with the presence of granular casts and tubular epithelial cells in the urine.
  • Pathologically, two main types are recognized: ischemic ATI, typically resulting from inadequate renal perfusion due to hypotension, trauma, or sepsis; and nephrotoxic ATI, caused by exposure to toxic agents such as drugs (e.g., aminoglycosides), heavy metals, or radiocontrast media.
  • The proximal tubular epithelium is especially susceptible due to its high energy requirements and exposure to reabsorbed toxic solutes.
  • Recovery is possible with regeneration of tubular epithelium if the basement membrane remains intact, but prolonged injury may result in chronic kidney disease.
  • Morphologically, ischemic ATI affects straight segments of proximal tubules and ascending limbs, showing tubular cell shedding and cast formation. In nephrotoxic ATI, necrosis is more severe in the proximal tubules.

Explanation of other options:

White blood cells casts(Option B): Can be seen in acute pyelonephritis.

Colloid casts (Option C): Can be seen in chronic pyelonephritis.

Red blood cell casts (Option D): It can be seen in nephritic syndrome and focal lupus nephritis,

questions.text: The following figure demonstrates a Masson trichrome preparation from a kidney biopsy showing complete replacement of virtually all glomeruli by blue-staining collagen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Masson trichrome staining is used to visualise collagen which is deposited in glomerulosclerosis and interstitial fibrosis, a feature of chronic kidney injury as seen in chronic glomerulonephritis.

  • Once renal disease begins and progresses, whether glomerular or otherwise, it initiates a cycle of nephron destruction and if it progresses to a state where the GFR is lowered to around 30 - 50% of normal, it goes on to end-stage renal failure (ESRD) regardless of the original etiology.
  • The two main pathological hallmarks of this progression are glomerulosclerosis ( focal or segmental) and is often a secondary outcome of other glomerular diseases, and tubulointerstitial fibrosis, which reflects damage to the tubular cells and surrounding interstitium.
  • Importantly, the extent of tubulointerstitial fibrosis correlates more closely with renal function decline than the severity of glomerular damage itself.
  • Various factors such as ischemia, proteinuria, and chronic inflammation contribute to this fibrotic process.

Explanation of other options:

Angiomyolipoma (Option A): Angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor of the kidney which arises from perivascular epithelioid cells made of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and fat, commonly associated with tuberous sclerosis and carries a risk of spontaneous bleeding.

Acute tubular necrosis (Option C): Acute tubular injury (ATI) (acute tubular necrosis) is marked by patchy tubular epithelial damage and cast formation, particularly affecting the proximal straight tubule and thick ascending limb. The injury also leads to epithelial cell damage, detachment, and basement membrane rupture (tubulorrhexis).

Renal cell cancer (Option D): Can arise anywhere in the kidney but favors the poles. Tumor cells of clear cell cancers (most common subtype) are round to polygonal with abundant clear occasionally granular cytoplasm. A delicate, arborizing vascular network typically courses between the cell clusters.

questions.text: A patient presented with pus in urine. Urine culture was done which was negative. After a sudden onset of renal failure, the patient died. On autopsy the following finding was seen in the kidney. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history of sterile pyuria and white cheesy caseous deposits suggests a case of tuberculosis of the kidney.

  • Genitourinary tuberculosis, the third most common extrapulmonary form of TB, spreads hematogenously from the lungs, often affecting immunocompromised individuals and causing a spectrum of urinary symptoms, renal dysfunction, and anatomical damage that may ultimately require both prolonged antibiotic treatment and surgical intervention.
  • Clinically, patients may present with urinary symptoms like dysuria, sterile pyuria, hematuria, and may progress to chronic kidney disease.
  • Diagnosis is supported by acid-fast bacilli in urine, positive culture results, imaging, and sometimes chest radiography.
  • Renal TB can cause either localized or diffuse glomerular injury, potentially progressing down the urinary tract to produce ureteric strictures or affect other organs like the epididymis.

Explanation of other options:

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (Option B): Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is marked by massively enlarged, cyst-filled kidneys, where cysts of varying content and epithelial linings arise from all nephron segments and may compress renal structures as they expand.

Renal cell carcinoma (Option C): Renal cell carcinoma, particularly clear cell type, commonly arises from proximal tubular epithelium and presents as sharply demarcated, yellow-gray-white masses with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage, often located at the kidney poles.

Renal stones (Option D): Renal stones are usually unilateral, commonly forming in the renal calyces, pelvis, or bladder, and may be small, smooth, irregular, or grow into large branching staghorn calculi that mold to the collecting system.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with purpuric skin lesions, abdominal pain, intestinal bleeding and arthralgia. Immunofluorescence study demonstrated IgA deposition as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of purpuric lesions, abdominal pain, and intestinal bleeding with IgA deposits on immunofluorescence suggests a diagnosis of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

  • Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP) is a childhood vasculitis characterized by IgA-dominant immune complex deposition.
  • It typically affects children aged 3 to 8 and presents with a triad of purpuric skin lesions (mainly on extensor surfaces), abdominal pain with possible bleeding, and arthralgia.
  • Renal involvement occurs in about a third of cases, ranging from hematuria to full-blown nephritic or nephrotic syndromes, and occasionally rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with crescents.
  • IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a pattern similar to IgA nephropathy, leading to the concept that HSP and IgA nephropathy are related.
  • Histologically, the renal lesions vary in severity, but immunofluorescence consistently shows IgA (with or without IgG and C3) in the mesangial region.
  • Skin and GI vasculitis is also noted, though kidney vasculitis is rare.
  • Prognosis is generally good in children, especially with mild disease, but adults and those with crescents or nephrotic syndrome have a worse outcome.

Explanation of other options:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (Option A): A common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults is characterized by segmental and focal glomerular sclerosis due to podocyte damage, manifesting with nephrotic syndrome features such as proteinuria, high blood pressure, blood in urine, and elevated nitrogenous waste.

Minimal change disease (Option B): The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children aged 2 to 6 is marked by diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes seen on electron microscopy, with no visible changes on light microscopy and no immune complex deposition.

Diabetic neuropathy (Option C): Diabetic nephropathy primarily affects the kidneys, with hallmark morphological changes including glomerular basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial expansion, and nodular glomerulosclerosis, which often leads to renal failure.These changes are often accompanied by hyalinosis, ischemia, and tubulointerstitial fibrosis, contributing to progressive loss of kidney function. Diabetic vascular lesions, including hyaline arteriolosclerosis of both afferent and efferent arterioles, also play a role in disease progression.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with blurring of vision. Urine examination showed proteinuria. Histopathology picture of kidney given below. What is not true about the finding in the associated condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of blurring of vision and proteinuria along with histolopathological examination revealing diffuse and nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstein Wilson nodules) suggests a diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy in which glomerular basement membrane thickening is seen.

  • Diabetic nephropathy is a major complication of diabetes and a leading cause of renal failure.
  • Morphologically, it is characterized by three principal glomerular lesions: (1) thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), detectable early by electron microscopy. (2) diffuse mesangial sclerosis, marked by widespread mesangial matrix expansion that is PAS-positive and correlates with proteinuria; and (3) nodular glomerulosclerosis, also known as Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions, which are laminated, PAS-positive spherical nodules in the glomerular periphery. (Options A and B ruled out)
  • These changes are often accompanied by hyalinosis, ischemia, and tubulointerstitial fibrosis, contributing to progressive loss of kidney function.
  • Diabetic vascular lesions, including hyaline arteriolosclerosis of both afferent and efferent arterioles, also play a role in disease progression. (Option D ruled out)
  • Pyelonephritis is more frequent and severe in diabetic patients, contributing to kidney damage.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presented with mild hematuria, pedal edema and frothy urine. BP 110/70 mm Hg. Subsequently he was treated with steroid but he did not improve. The renal biopsy was carried out. The electron microscopy finding has been shown. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

History given here is that of nephrotic syndrome and electron microscopy shows flattening of foot processes of podocytes, a feature of minimal change disease.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic male found to have microalbuminuria. Identify the lesion shown in renal biopsy of this patient.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this case, kidney biopsy from a patient suffering from diabetic nephropathy shows nodular glomerulosclerosis suggested by diffuse increase in mesangial matrix and characteristic acellular PAS-positive nodules.
